review.title: Classifying discourse in a CSCL platform to evaluate correlations with Teacher Participation and Progress
review.abstract: In Computer-Supported learning, monitoring and engaging a group of learners is a complex task for teachers, especially when learners are working collaboratively: Are my students motivated? What kind of progress are they making? Should I intervene? Is my communication and the didactic design adapted to my students? Our hypothesis is that the analysis of natural language interactions between students, and between students and teachers, provide very valuable information and could be used to produce qualitative indicators to help teachers' decisions. We develop an automatic approach in three steps (1) to explore the discursive functions of messages in a CSCL platform, (2) to classify the messages automatically and (3) to evaluate correlations between discursive attitudes and other variables linked to the learning activity. Results tend to show that some types of discourse are correlated with a notion of Progress on the learning activities and the importance of emotive participation from the Teacher.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1.1 ICT challenges in Education
sections.text: The emergence of massive open online courses (Coursera, edX, OpenClassrooms), e-learning platforms (Moodle, KhanAcademy) and computer-based collaborative learning platforms (CSCL) (Metafora, Claroline) opens a new horizon in terms of knowledge formation and dissemination. At the same time, Blended Learning [1] is a growing educational program in formal education that combines traditional teaching and distance learning via web platforms such as the Kelluwen Project [33]. Several considerations accompany this paradigm shift in education. We group these research lines under four challenges: 1) How to optimize the motivation and satisfaction of learners? (also called engagement) 2) How to optimize the skills acquisition and performance of learners? (also called progress) 3) How to predict learning behavior (engagement / discouragement, progress / mental block, learning style, etc.) How to optimize the role of the teacher?

sections.heading: 1.2 The Natural Language: A source of data to explore the cognitive phenomena related to Learning
sections.text: In the context of the CSCL, particular attention is paid to the development of interactions between learners. However, collaboration theory assumes that knowledge is not just a matter of memorising a list of facts, but is dynamically constructed through social relationships, joint activities and dialogues. [16] For this reason, social media (forums, chatrooms, microblogs, video conferences) play a particularly central role in the CSCL platforms [17] and socio-communicative skills play a key role in knowledge building. By analysing dialogues between learners on the CSCL platforms, previous studies have shown that various linguistic and cognitive phenomena influence or correlate the progress and engagement of learners: 1) mutual listening and dialogical cohesion [18] [19], 2) expression of positive / negative emotions [21], 3) expression of uncertainty and questioning [22] [23], 4) quality of reasoning and vocabulary used [25].

sections.heading: 1.3 Overview of the research problem addressed in this article
sections.text: In this article, we automate the analysis of the discourse of students and teachers in a CSCL platform and then examine how discursive phenomena correlate with other variables, such as the quantitative involvement of teachers, the degree of progress of learning activities or the didactic design applied. We believe that our work can be used to better assist teachers in monitoring the development of learning activities and to assist curriculum planners in developing better learning activities.Our methodology is divided into three steps. First, we use machine learning techniques to explore latent topics and discover discursive categories present in teachers "messages. Second, we automatically classify the messages according to their main discursive categories. Finally, we examine correlations between different variables related to learning activities and discursive behaviors observed in the previous step. Data used in our experiments comes from the CSCL platform Kelluwen [33].

sections.heading: 2 RELATED WORK

sections.heading: 2.1 Related work in NLP
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to survive on their own.

sections.heading: 2.2 Related works in Linguistics
sections.text: In linguistics, the concept of discourse implies that the true meaning of a sentence cannot be assigned by its sole linguistic construction, but is largely determined by the communication situation within which it was pronounced. In other words, in order to properly understand a sentence, a first step is to find out what its main function is in the communication situation and to answer the question: "What is the purpose of this message?" The well-known model of language functions introduced by Roman Jakobson [39] (Figure 2) defines six main communication functions according to which an effective act of verbal communication can be described: 1) the emotional function: the intention of the message focuses on the emotions and attitudes of the speaker towards what he is talking about. Example: "I have difficulty understanding the exercise" 2) the conative function: it focuses on the interlocutor who tries to influence his behavior through an order or by persuasion. Example: "Moving in groups of two or three metaphors."

sections.heading: 3 THE KELLUWEN PROJECT AND THE DATASET
sections.text: The Kelluwen project is an attempt to integrate the effective use of blended learning into the formal curriculum of public education in southern Chile. It specifically focuses on the development of socio-communication skills of middle and high school students and the use of computerized collaborative tools as didactic resources. It includes a CSCL web platform that supports learning activities by providing access to materials and tools to facilitate communication and monitoring of work (Fig. 1).

sections.heading: 3.1 The Kelluwen Web platform
sections.text: In the project, a series of didactic designs (DD) has been developed to work on three subjects: language, history and technology. A DD covers a unit of content as defined in the curriculum of Chile's public schools, and contains a series of activities that combine traditional classroom learning strategies with the use of social web tools such as WordPress, Youtube, etc. In this way, Kelluwen aims to translate the sharing and communication skills of the Social Web into formal learning activities in schools.A typical DD contains a sequence of 8 to 12 classroom activities lasting between 1 and 1 / 2 hours (typical lecture time).In DD, students work in teams with the aim of creating a result that is eventually published in a social web tool, enabling further peer review processes.To achieve this, activities are organized in three phases: 1) a motivational phase in which students are presented concepts and themes, they must start and integrate knowledge.

sections.heading: 3.2 The dataset
sections.text: The average length of a message is 7.3 words and 44.8 characters, which makes it quite short even for a microblog post. As the logbook was explicitly intended as an informal channel, the messages also contain a lot of slang, emoticons and misspelled words. The messages are distributed according to the following criteria: • 20128 messages from students, 1084 from teachers; • 9631 messages from middle school, 11581 from high school; • 11341 messages expressed in the language during 51 didactic experiences; 8226 messages from history (43 experiences); 1655 messages from technology (17 experiences).The message distribution of students in the class groups has a median of 135, that is 185, a standard deviation of 180, and a maximum of 1104 messages in a class of a group of 5 messages.

sections.heading: 3.3 Data preprocessing
sections.text: In order to facilitate the machine learning processes presented in sections 4 and 5, we developed a series of natural language pre-processing to normalize the representation of messages. 1) Tokenization: a message is segmented into words; 2) Lemmatization: the words are commented on with their generic forms (the problem). The problem of activdades (activities) is, for example, actividad (activity). For this module, we used the Spanish lemmatization model available in the TreeTagger tool [41], 3) Stopword filtering: a short list of grammatical words (such as aquel (das), cada (each)) are filtered to simplify the vectorial representation of messages; 4) Basic spell correction: In the same idea, several slight spelling errors are corrected by using regular expressions. In particular, it concerns some words that contain multiple vowels that perform such asuooooooooooooooooo (goooooood).

sections.heading: 4 EXPLORING TOPICS IN MESSAGES
sections.text: The first step of our methodology is mainly exploratory. We take an unmonitored LDA approach to uncover latent issues in the dataset. The goal is to get a first look at the content of the messages from learners and teachers to help us understand the linguistic attitudes on the Kelluwen CSCL platform.

sections.heading: 5 CLASSIFYING MESSAGES
sections.text: In the first step, we examined the messages of learners and teachers and identified that they could be divided into three discursive categories: Emotional, Phatic and Referential. The second step is to evaluate the feasibility of automating the classification of messages. Based on a reference corpus, we developed and evaluated two statistical models based on LDA and SVM to classify messages from the Kelluwen platform.

sections.heading: 5.1 Reference corpus & Manual annotation
sections.text: To form a reference corpus, 500 messages were randomly selected from the original data set. Subsequently, 3 human judges determined the most important discursive function of each of the three functions identified in the previous step (emotive, phatic or referential). We used the Fleiss kappa [42] to measure the reliability of the agreement between the judges. For this task, the Fleiss kappa is 0.70, which is a good match according to the scale proposed by Landis et al. [43]. In other words, even if this task can be complex for humans in some cases (when messages have a really bad syntax or, for example, contain only one emoticon), most people are able to understand the intention with which a message was sent. Finally, the category for each message in the reference corpus is that which was selected by at least two judges. There are no cases in which all judges disagreed with the other two.

sections.heading: 5.2 Classification methods
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 SVM
sections.text: The first method is based on an SVM-monitored learning approach. For each message, we apply the preprocessing described in Section 3.3 to form a vector representation. In addition to the class of the message, the vector attributes are the general form of words that exist in the entire corpus (excluding the stopwords), which in this case are 1,543 words. The attribute value is binary and indicates whether the word occurs in the message or not. For example, the vector representation of the example (1) contains three attributes with the value "1": no, entender (understand) and ": - (." Other attributes (the other 1,540 words) have the value "0." (1) No Entendo: - (I do not understand: - ((emotional) For our experiment, we used the Sequential Minimum Optimization Algorithm (SMO) available in the Weka library.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 LDA
sections.text: The second method of automatic classification of messages is based on the LDA approach presented in Section 4. In LDA, each word has a probability of belonging to a specific topic. Therefore, this classifier simply calculates the probability that a message belongs to class Ci as the product of the probability that each word of the message belongs to class Ci. The class with the best probability is the class held by this classifier. Since LDA is not directly suitable for a supervised classification, this classifier is mainly used as a starting point to evaluate the SVM classification. 6 LDA SVM class P R F1 P R F1Phatic 84.9% 59.0% 69.6% 87.6% 97.9% 92.5% 94.6% 73.0% 73.8% 73.8% 73.8% 73.8% 100.0% 100.0% 100.0% Reference class 47.2% 76.4% 58.4% 94.7% 72.6% 72.8% 72.8% Total 67.8% 67.1% of classification messages with class 92.8% SVM.

sections.heading: 5.3 Classification results & Discussion
sections.text: To determine the effectiveness of both classifiers, we use 3 classic metrics in the text classification: (1) precision (P) measures the system's ability to avoid irrelevant solutions, the Recall (R) measures the system's ability to provide all relevant solutions, and the F1 score (F1) is the harmonious mean between precision and recall. A general overview of the results (Table 2) tends to show that discursive classification of short messages on the CSCL platform can be achieved automatically, even if texts are loud.

sections.heading: 6.1 Classification of all the messages
sections.text: Using the SVM model we trained and evaluated in the previous step, we classified the 20,128 messages from students in the data set. According to this automatic classification, the data set contains 9,984 Phatic messages (median 61 per class group and standard deviation 122), 3,341 Referential messages (median: 18, standard deviation: 33) and 7,704 Emotive messages (median: 41, standard deviation: 94). In addition, we classified the 1,084 messages from teachers (44 Phatics, 199 Referentials and 841 Emotives). For each class group, we calculate the proportion of each of these categories. These variables are called Phatic, Referential and Emotives, with a suffix S or T indicating whether it is the percentage in the messages from students or teachers.

sections.heading: 6.2 Description of the other variables considered
sections.text: For each group, we also consider the following variables: • Teacher Participation: This variable is calculated as a percentage of teacher messages about all messages posted in a class group and is referred to as Teacher Participation. • Number of students: This corresponds to the number of students who belong to each class group. It is not necessarily the same number of students who participate in posting on the microblog. This factor is referred to as Student. • Progress of Experience: Some class groups have never completed the didactic design. This variable is calculated as a percentage of completed activities in each class group and is referred to as progress. • Regularity of activities: This is measured by determining the daily differences between activities and determining the mean and variance for each class group, so that a small mean and variance imply regularity.

sections.heading: 6.3 Correlation results & Discussion
sections.text: In statistics, the interpretation of a correlation coefficient x (x [− 1, + 1]) is a complex task. It is generally assumed that there is a strong correlation when | x | is close to 0.7, a weak correlation when | x | is close to 0.3, and no correlation when | x | is close to 0. In our case, since we work with linguistic phenomena, it may be interesting to observe results with less stringent criteria, while remaining critical in interpretation.7

sections.heading: 6.3.1 Correlation matrix
sections.text: In the correlation matrix (Tab. 3), we observe that there are several strong correlations between the variables mean / variance (x = 0.64), Phatic S / referential S (x = -0.71) and Emotive S / Phatic S (x = -0.77). These variables are correlated by definition, but we can still observe how the Phatic variable relates negatively to the other two discursive categories. A more interesting correlation is that between the students "progress and attitudes: Phatic S (x = 0.19), Referential S (x = 0.12) and Emotive S (x = 0.15). We might think that chatting (excessive phatic communication) has a bad influence on learning success. On the contrary, students" emotional or referential attitudes seem to be marginally related to progress.

sections.heading: 6.3.2 Principal Components Analysis
sections.text: Figure 3 shows a two-dimensional representation in which correlations can be observed, as the arrows point to the same (positive correlations), opposite (negative correlations) or orthogonal (no correlations) direction. Each arrow is one of the variables considered, with the numbers of the didactic design ID positioned in the figure corresponding to each experience. Thus, for example, didactic design 21 (language activity via YouTube) is often associated with progress, emotional messages from teachers, and reference messages from students. In this sense, discursive analysis of messages could also be used to help teachers or designers select and develop better learning activities. Additionally, this figure confirms a fairly strong negative correlation between progress and the average number of days between activities (variable mean).

sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this article, we show that the analysis of natural interactions between students and teachers provides valuable information that could help teachers in their decisions regarding computer-aided learning. We demonstrated the ability to automate the analysis of these interactions, even when texts are short and loud. By using a combination of unsupervised and supervised machine learning techniques, we found that the messages of learners and teachers can be automatically classified according to three communication intentions described by Jakobson: creating or maintaining a communication channel (Phatic), exchanging information about the learning context (Referential) and expressing an emotion or a subjective attitude (Emotive). Results of a correlation calculation show that the types of discourse used by learners tend to have a relationship with the teacher qualitative participation and progress of learning activity.

What kind of progress are they making? Should I intervene? Is my communication and the didactic design adapted to my students? Our hypothesis is that the analysis of natural language interactions between students, and between students and teachers, provide very valuable information and could be used to produce qualitative indicators to help teachers’ decisions. We develop an automatic approach in three steps (1) to explore the discursive functions of messages in a CSCL platform, (2) to classify the messages automatically and (3) to evaluate correlations between discursive attitudes and other variables linked to the learning activity. Results tend to show that some types of discourse are correlated with a notion of Progress on the learning activities and the importance of emotive participation from the Teacher.
